props.synopsis: Canberra Health Services said it received a "lot of feedback" on the post and had removed it for fear of it being "misinterpreted". It will now meet with members of a Canberra endometriosis support group who expressed concern about the messaging.

title.children: Woman in extreme endometriosis pain says health authority's social video deterred her from seeking emergency help

image.altText: Protesters sit down and chant at the Australian National University pro-Palestine encampment.

props.synopsis: The ANU has announced it will no longer invest in certain weapons companies in the long term, following months of pressure from pro-Palestinian student groups.

title.children: ANU to stop long-term investments in 'controversial' weapons manufacturers following months-long Gaza protest on campus

image.altText: Judge Salvatore Vasta

props.synopsis: The High Court will today seek to decide whether judges can be sued for making an error in sentencing, in the wake of a man successfully suing a Federal Circuit Court judge for wrongful imprisonment.

title.children: High Court to decide if judges can be sued for making a mistake

image.altText: A man with short light brown hair in a navy suit looks offended as he reaches for a car door handle while standing in a carpark.

props.synopsis: A Canberra gambler hoping for "a big win" is convicted of fraud after stealing more than $70,000 from the Master Builders Association while working as an event organiser for the association.

title.children: Canberra gambler avoids jail for stealing over $70,000 from Master Builders Association

image.altText: A digital composite image of Brittany Higgins, Scott Morrison and Linda Reynolds' faces.

props.synopsis: Despite being heralded as a star witness in the case, it remains to be seen how former prime minister Scott Morrison's recollections will be much more than peripheral to the Brittany Higgins defamation trial.

title.children: Scott Morrison’s robust court testimony for Linda Reynolds a reminder of a different era in politics

image.altText: A woman sits at an outdoor cafe table.

props.synopsis: A new ACT government team will review building designs and attend inspections alongside private certifiers to reduce the prevalence of defects in high-rise buildings.

title.children: Anne's been dealing with defects in her apartment for years. It's hoped a new team of certifiers will protect others

image.altText: A man in a suit looking grim.

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese has defended his approach on visa approvals as Peter Dutton says people fleeing Gaza should not be allowed into Australia. Follow live.

title.children: Government faces questions over Gazan visas, PM defends approach

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Figures reveal most visas for people fleeing Gaza are being refused
Dutton asks first question about Gazan visas
A deal on the CFMEU bill a step closer

image.altText: Generic photos of apartments, balconies

props.synopsis: The Coalition is developing a policy to lower the barriers for would-be homebuyers to get a loan, as part of an election pitch to "aspirational" young Australians within sight of home ownership.

title.children: Coalition to push for first homebuyers to get easier access to home loans

image.altText: A person wearing a hoodie and track pants, throws a piece of wood at a building as a large crowd watches on.

props.synopsis: ABC NEWS Verify used a tool called CrowdTangle to help up-end a disinformation operation on Facebook that was targeting the UK riots. Now, Meta is killing off CrowdTangle for good.

title.children: The 'Musk effect' has allowed social media platforms to turbocharge the UK riots

image.altText: a young girl

props.synopsis: Yingying Xu, 46, has been charged with the murder of her daughter at their home on Tuesday.

title.children: Mother charged with murder of 10-year-old daughter on the Gold Coast

image.altText: Teenage students solve maths problems in workbooks.

props.synopsis: One in three Australian school students is not meeting literacy and numeracy benchmarks, and more than one in ten need additional support, the 2024 NAPLAN results show.

title.children: One in three students failing to meet English and maths standards, NAPLAN data shows

image.altText: Men walking with the golden dome of the rock behind them.

props.synopsis: Israel's national security minister's precariously timed visit to the Temple Mount in Jerusalem has prompted fury and condemnation. Here's why.

title.children: A hard-line politician visited one of the holiest sites for Muslims and Jews. Here's why that's controversial

image.altText: a young woman holds up a green 'P' plate

props.synopsis: Assessors falling asleep mid-test, teens lying in their logbooks, and busloads of metro learners going regional. These are the ways Australian drivers are cheating the drivers licence system.

title.children: Australians 'gaming the system' to get drivers licences as road deaths rise again

image.altText: Finlaey Hewlett standing and looking at a body of water

props.synopsis: A global consortium of world-leading mental health experts and young people have come together to deliver a definitive analysis of the worldwide state of youth mental health, calling for urgent action to "tackle a global crisis".

title.children: 'It's so much more expensive to just be a human nowadays': The megatrends behind rising distress in young people

image.altText: Footy players jump in the air to catch the ball during a game, while a bet365 ad blinks from the stadium.

props.synopsis: The degree of trepidation with which the federal government is this week mincing around even the second-order question of banning gambling ads — just the ads! — gives you a very pungent sense of just how powerful this industry is.

title.children: Gambling ads don't fund our TV networks. We all know who really pays the cost

image.altText: Dutton looks out of frame while sitting at the despatch box in the lower house.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton says Palestinians fleeing Gaza should not be granted entry to Australia, as figures from the home affairs department reveal most applications are being refused.

title.children: Two thirds of people seeking to flee Gaza to Australia being refused

image.altText: Three small buildings reduced to rubble.

props.synopsis: Angry Russians displaced after Ukraine crossed the border and invaded the Kursk region last week have vented their frustrations online to President Vladimir Putin, as Kyiv says its forces are capturing more ground.

title.children: Putin is enraged as Ukraine suddenly decides to invade Russia. Here's the strategy behind the audacious move

image.altText: Tony Armstrong standing in front of Syndey Harbour with a giant gold logie

props.synopsis: In less than five years, Tony Armstrong has gone from ex-AFL player to one of TV's most recognisable faces, winning two Logies along the way.

title.children: As a kid, Tony Armstrong wasn't allowed to watch TV. Now he's up for the Gold Logie

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has cut interest rates to 5.25 per cent, while Australia's corporate regulator has announced it's suing the ASX for alleged misleading statements. Look back on the day's events with our blog.

title.children: Reserve Bank of NZ cuts interest rates as ASIC sues ASX for alleged misleading statements — as it happened

image.altText: A man in suit and tie sits in an office, looking serious.

props.synopsis: In a statement ASX managing director and CEO Helen Lofthouse said, "We recognise the significance and serious nature of these proceedings."

title.children: ASIC takes stock exchange to court for alleged 'very significant corporate governance failure'

image.altText: A panel of three photos of Karthik Sivasubramanian, Lucky Singh Saini and Surya Kant, who appear serious.

props.synopsis: The ABC has spoken to more than a dozen people who allege they lost their life savings after investing with Melbourne businessman Amit Miglani, who some accuse of leveraging trust to target members of Australia's Indian community.

title.children: 'He's totally a conman': These Indian-Australian migrants allege they've lost thousands in a property scam targeting their community

image.altText: Ash Grunwald

props.synopsis: After 35 years, one of Australia's most iconic music festivals will hold its "final curtain call". Musicians and community members are devastated by the news.

title.children: 'Like a loved one dying': Musicians and locals mourn demise of Byron's Bluesfest

image.altText: Woman seen from behind in bright yellow jacket stands with one hand on hip, and blurred, tree-lined street ahead of her.

props.synopsis: Restorative justice is a long process that culminates in a meeting between a victim-survivor and the person responsible for their harm. It's complex and powerful, and those who've been through it say it can deliver meaningful results.

title.children: These sexual assault victims got accountability from their abusers — but it wasn't through the legal system

image.altText: Fumio Kishida

props.synopsis: Fumio Kishida's decision to quit will trigger a contest to replace him as Japan's ruling party boss, and by extension as the leader of the world's fourth-biggest economy.

title.children: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida to step down in September

image.altText: Aboriginal man with ceremonial paint on, holding boomerang.

props.synopsis: The Wiradyuri people of the NSW Central West want acknowledgement of the true history of one of Australia's first settlements.

title.children: Push for Bathurst to grapple with its brutal past in Wiradyuri-led truth-telling project

image.altText: Patrick Cripps, James Sicily and Zach Merrett

props.synopsis: In an AFL season where the gap between the best and worst has been minuscule at times, timing the run into the finals has been more important as ever. Here are the teams that have done it to perfection while others have missed the mark.

title.children: How Hawks timed finals run to perfection as Blues and Bombers collapsed in AFL season like no other

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD

props.synopsis: The Commonwealth Bank has posted a profit of $9.5 billion, down 6 per cent from its record results last financial year, while noting that younger Australians are bearing the brunt of the impact of the rising cost of living.

title.children: Commonwealth Bank finds younger Australians are spending less, after posting profit of $9.5 billion

image.altText: Dual Paris Olympics gold medal-winning canoeist Jess Fox arriving in Sydney

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and the athletes' families were on hand to greet the triumphant Australian team at Sydney Airport this morning.

title.children: 'Coming home is the best feeling': Olympic team touches down after record gold haul

image.altText: Two chocolate muffins cooling on a wooden board, with some chocolate shavings. One has fallen on it's side.

props.synopsis: One of the surprise stars of the Paris Olympics, at least on social media, was a decadent chocolate muffin served in the cafeteria inside the Olympic village.

title.children: The Olympics might be over, but the village chocolate muffin hype continues

image.altText: Four members of Aussie band Grinspoon pose in suits on white photo screen.

props.synopsis: From a surprise Jack White release to the latest from Aussie music mainstays, here's five albums worth your time this week.

title.children: Grinspoon's new album reminds us why we fell for them in the first place

props.synopsis: Canberra Health Services said it received a "lot of feedback" on the post and had removed it for fear of it being "misinterpreted". It will now meet with members of a Canberra endometriosis support group who expressed concern about the messaging.

title.children: Woman in extreme endometriosis pain says health authority's social video deterred her from seeking emergency help

image.altText: Blake Wilson

props.synopsis: A helicopter piloted by Nautilus Aviation ground crew member Blake Wilson crashed into the Double Tree Hilton in Cairns early Monday morning, killing him and injuring two guests.

title.children: Investigators say 'lessons may emerge' based on evidence collected from Cairns helicopter crash

image.altText: A man walks away from a mobile phone tower in the outback.

props.synopsis: Telstra and Optus will delay the planned closure of their 3G networks in order to conduct a final public safety awareness campaign amid concerns that emergency services calls and medical devices could be affected.

title.children: Telstra, Optus to delay 3G network closure amid public safety concerns

image.altText: A pineapple flavoured sweet in a yellow wrapper

props.synopsis: The amount of methamphetamine in each lolly was up to 300 times the level someone would usually take and could be lethal.

title.children: Meth-filled lollies unknowingly distributed by New Zealand food bank

image.altText: Side by side images of the ruins of a church (left) and a gravestone from 1904 (right).

props.synopsis: Buying an old or ruined church can bring great possibilities as well as responsibilities, particularly if your new neighbours' ancestors are buried in your garden.

title.children: Historic church for sale, complete with its own graveyard
